title: 'We're not leaving,' say attorneys at DFW Airport as reports of detained travelers mount
text:
'We're not leaving,' say attorneys at DFW Airport as reports of detained travelers mount Filed under Immigration at Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
A group of Dallas-area attorneys aiding travelers affected by President Donald Trump's executive order on immigration said Wednesday that they will maintain their legal "war room" at DFW International Airport for as long as needed. 
Chris Hamilton, an owner and partner of the Standly and Hamilton LLP law firm, told reporters that attorneys were aware of at least 30 travelers who had been "inappropriately detained" at DFW Airport, including the nine who were released Sunday. He also announced that he would champion the legal efforts to protect the travelers with a personal donation of $100,000 with attorney Lisa Blue. 
"We're not leaving until the job is done," he said at a gathering Wednesday that was part news conference and part revival, with a large crowd shouting their support and speeches by attorneys praising one another and the demonstrators. 
Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins and former Dallas City Council member Angela Hunt, a private attorney, were also at the news conference. So was Imam Omar Suleiman, who helped lead the weekend protests at the airport, and other faith leaders. 
Trump signed an order Friday that for three months will bar entry to travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries: Iraq, Iran, Lybia, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. He also suspended the refugee program for four months and banned Syrian refugees indefinitely. 
Civil rights advocates promptly challenged the order in federal courts, where judges have temporarily blocked Trump's restrictions. 
Some travelers detained at DFW Airport on Saturday told attorneys that they had been asked to sign papers expediting their removal. A stay against Trump's order was granted in a New York court late the same day, and those travelers were eventually released. 
But since that time, others are still being held for hours at a time and being submitted to intrusive screening, according to the attorneys. They described how travelers were being asked about their religion and how authorities were extracting information from their cell phones. 
Hamilton said orders are coming from Washington, D.C., to continue enforcing the travel restrictions, but he said it was unclear who was giving the instructions. 
"It's a black hole of information," he said. 
There is no public tally from an official source about the number of people who've been held at DFW Airport or submitted to additional screening as a result of Trump's order. Hamilton said lawyers are getting their information from travelers, their families and "public servants." He declined to give specifics about any travelers who may be in custody right now, citing the attorneys' desire to protect their clients. 
Customs and Border Protection representatives haven't returned multiple requests seeking comment. 
Federal officials can stop travelers coming into the United States for any number of reasons, such as concerns about contact with livestock or gifts being brought into the country. But some travelers have been held for more than four hours. 
One wheelchair-bound Iraqi man was held for 15 hours even though he carried a special immigrant visa for helping the U.S. Army, according to attorneys. Hamilton and others had filed an emergency court petition asking for the man's release. Iraqi in wheelchair released after 15-hour detention at DFW Airport under Trump's travel ban 
The Department of Homeland Security explained Sunday that permanent residents, or green-card holders, from the seven countries in Trump's order won't be barred from re-entering the United States. At DFW Airport, however, most of the travelers who have been held are green-card holders, Hamilton said. 
The attorneys in the "war room" at the airport are working pro bono. A GoFundMe page on behalf of the group is collecting donations to pay for the hotel conference room they've been using and supplies. 
While community leaders hosted vigils in support of Muslims and immigrants early this week, activism in the international terminal at DFW Airport has quieted down. Attorneys continue to sit near the arrival doors to offer assistance to families of travelers who may have been stopped. View Comments
